After everybody came back from being dusted, people tried very hard to return back to normal and in your town, people decided that living life normally meant throwing a carnival. You weren’t complaining and you promised that you were going to try to play pretend along with everybody so that you could return to your normal life, whatever your normal life was like five years ago.

Kylee, your best friend, invited you to come to the carnival with her boyfriend, Xavier and you agreed, hoping you would be reminded of the good old times you spent with Kylee. You three went on a couple rides together and the roller coasters were able to fit all of you three so splitting up the group wasn’t a problem. After going on a couple rides, Kylee wanted to ride the Ferris wheel since she wanted to watch the romantic sunset with Xavier, claiming that it would be an amazing view since the Ferris wheel overlooked a glossy lake.

Before you got in line for the Ferris wheel, you got cotton candy and Kylee watched Xavier attempt to win a stuffed animal for her by throwing darts at balloons. Afterward, you guys went to board the Ferris wheel and to your disappointment, the Ferris wheel booths could only hold two people at a time so you allowed Kylee to go with Xavier. When you boarded onto the booth, the ride operator told you that you weren’t allowed to be alone in your booth and a girl boarded the booth, sitting next to you.

At first, you felt a bit uncomfortable about being on a ride with a stranger but the girl was actually quite pretty. She wore a crocodile green jacket with jean shorts with a blue and red t-shirt. Her hair was cut in a short pixie bob cut and she radiated big lesbian energy. For some reason, she looked vaguely familiar but you couldn’t recall where you saw her before.

“Your shirt is really patriotic,” You blurted out by accident as the ride started, the booth slowly ascending. The girl turned towards you, appearing to be pleasantly surprised as she tugged at the ends of her jacket.

“Really? I didn’t notice that! I guess I’m just used to wearing these colors. I’m Carol by the way,” Carol stuck out a hand, her smile shining brighter than the light of the sun and stars combined. You shook her hand, smiling back as the panic mode in your brain turned on, reminding you that you hadn’t talked with a pretty girl in ages. The last time you flirted with somebody, you stumbled over your words and ended up ruining the moment so you silently promised yourself that you were going to stay calm during this interaction.

“Oh, I’m Y/n! Um, how’s your day going?” You attempted to start a conversation to ease the slowly eroding tension since you knew that silence with strangers always made you uncomfortable. As the ride briefly stopped to let some more people on, the booth rocked slightly, causing a piece of Carol’s hair to fall on her forehead. She casually pushed the hair back and you tried not to seem like that simple gesture stole your oxygen supply.

“I’ve been exploring the town for a bit. I haven’t been here in a while because of traveling,” Carol stared off into the distance, taking in the view of the town as she wistfully replied.

“To where? If you don’t mind me asking,” Carol turned back to face you again, her lips curling into another small smile as you asked the question.

“Let’s just say somewhere very far from here. What are you here for?” Her eyes flashed with a spark of something undetectable, possibly mischief or affection (although there is not much of a difference between those two), as she asked.

“A friend invited me to come with her and her boyfriend. I wish this was a double date but as you can probably tell, I don’t have a partner to ride romantic Ferris wheel rides with,” You joked, hoping that she enjoyed sarcastic humor and to your delight, your remark earned a giggle from her.

“Yeah, same here. My girlfriend broke up with me because I was ‘too liberal’ for her,” Carol explained, using air quotes to emphasize the absurdity of the accusation and rolled her eyes as she continued to explain. “All I did was try to advocate for equal rights but I guess she didn’t care and thought that equal rights don’t matter.”

“Ouch, that sucks big time,” You offered a sympathetic remark just as the Ferris wheel abruptly halted to a stop. Your booth was at the very top of the Ferris wheel and it was swinging back and forth due to the sudden stop. You glanced down at the ground to see the operator pushing buttons and pulling levers at the operating station, clearly panicking.

“Well, I guess this means we’re stuck here together” You commented, not particularly anxious about being stuck in a Ferris wheel with a very attractive and sweet girl.

“I don’t mind. Hey, can I have some of that cotton candy? It looks delicious,” Carol glanced at the cotton candy then looking up at you, an innocent, child-like look in her eyes.

“Sure!” You grabbed a tuft of cotton candy from the cone of cotton candy in your hand and handed it to Carol. Carol excitedly put the cotton candy in her mouth and ate it, smiling the whole time.

“Mm, this is amazing! I think this is the best cotton candy I’ve ever had in my life!” Carol commented, her smile widened as the sweetness of the cotton candy registering in her taste buds.

“It really is amazing,” You agreed, staring off into the distance and silently admiring the view. The sun was slowly sinking into the horizon and the sunset reflected into the smooth surface of the water’s lake. The view was as breathtaking as Kylee promised and you breathlessly thought aloud, “The view is really beautiful.”

“Quite honestly, I think you’re prettier than the sunset,” Carol quipped casually and then she noticed your intense blush spreading across your cheeks. Instinctively, she brought her hands up to her mouth and gasped, “Did I just say that out loud? Oh my gosh, I’m so sorry if I made you uncomfortable. I know you’re single and I respect that and I’m so sorry I said that. It totally just slipped from my mouth.”

“No, it’s okay! Don’t worry about it. And actually, I’ve been looking for ‘the one’ for a while but you know, since people dissolved and came back after five years, it’s hard to find somebody among all this chaos,” You lightheartedly replied, trying to laugh off the slightly harrowing topic you accidentally brought up.

“Oh, yeah I’m sorry. These past few years have been difficult,” Carol admitted, seeming to be a little lost in her memories of the past few years. You noticed how uncomfortable how quickly Carol’s demeanor changed at the mention of the dusting.

“No, it’s really okay. I, uh, think you’re really pretty too,” You bashfully flirted, feeling the blush returning to your face. Carol’s beautiful smile returned as she beamed at your remark.

“If we ever get off this thing, do you maybe want to ride the carousel or something together? I would love to get to know you better. You’re a really cool person.”

“Sure! But if we’re stuck up here forever, you better not finish all our food supply within the next twenty-two minutes,” You dramatically shielded your cotton candy from Carol, gaining a laugh from her.

“No worries. Even if I do finish our food supply, I can always scale the side of this giant wheel with you in my arms and safely land on the ground,” Carol retorted, a dead serious expression on her face that broke into delight when you broke out in wheezing laughter.

“Sound romantic,” You responded, grinning as Carol laughed along with you. Abruptly, the booth lurched forward as the Ferris wheel began working again. Your hand accidentally landed onto Carol’s as you almost crashed into her. You quickly apologized and you two sat silently in the booth, glancing shyly at each other as the booth reached the bottom of the Ferris wheel.

As you got off of the Ferris wheel, you saw Kylee and she quickly ran over to you, “You’re okay! I was worried about you! That was really scary. Xavier and I are going to get some hot dogs to calm down before going on any other rides. Want to come?”

You glanced over at Carol, who was expectantly waiting for you by the exit of the Ferris wheel and answered, “Actually, I think I’ll pass. I promised somebody a carousel ride.”

~
